title: When is it OK to use the first person in technical reports? - Quora

response.answer_text: It’s fine to use first and second person in a technical report for clarity’s sake. For instance, if you want to use it in discussing assumptions you used in your methodology, go ahead. As discussed in detail in Michael Alley’s The Craft of Scientific Writing, such writing can be easier to understand and clearer (Instead of “It was decided that…” or “The authors made the assumption…”). Most of the time, however, you’re going to stick with third person construction since you want to keep the emphasis on your work, not you.

I like Julie Martin’s answer. My opinion is that you should definitely use the first person if there is definitely a need (for clarity, simplicity, etc.) to use it. But, in fact, I have never found a need to refer to myself in technical documentation.
